factoid: It was St. Natalia’s day.
It was the name day of two Rostóvs.
The two Rostóvs were the mother and the youngest daughter.
Both Rostóvs were named Nataly.
From the morning, carriages with six horses had been coming and going continually.
The carriages were bringing visitors to the Countess Rostóva’s big house on the Povarskáya.
The Countess Rostóva’s big house on the Povarskáya is well known to all of Moscow.
The countess herself was in the drawing room.
The countess’s handsome eldest daughter was in the drawing room.
Visitors came to congratulate.
Visitors constantly succeeded one another in relays.
The countess was about forty-five years old.
The countess had a thin Oriental type of face.
The countess was evidently worn out with childbearing.
The countess had had twelve children.
The countess’s motion and speech were languorous.
The countess’s languor resulted from weakness.
The countess’s distinguished air inspired respect.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna Drubetskáya was a member of the household.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna Drubetskáya was seated in the drawing room.
Princess Anna Mikháylovna Drubetskáya helped to receive and entertain the visitors.
The young people were in one of the inner rooms.
The young people did not consider it necessary to take part in receiving the visitors.
The count met the guests.
The count saw the guests off.
The count invited the guests to dinner.
The count called everyone "mon cher" or "ma chère" without exception.
The count called everyone "my dear" regardless of rank.
The count thanked himself and the two dear ones whose name day they were keeping.
The count told the guests to come to dinner or he would be offended.
The count begged the guests to come on behalf of the whole family.
The count repeated these words to everyone without exception or variation.
The count had a full, cheerful, clean‑shaven face.
The count had a firm pressure of the hand.
The count made quick, repeated bows.
After seeing a visitor off, the count returned to the drawing room.
The count drew a chair toward the visitor.
The count spread his legs and put his hands on his knees.
The count had an air of a man who enjoys life and knows how to live.
The count swayed to and fro with dignity.
The count offered surmises about the weather.
The count touched on questions of health.
The count spoke sometimes in Russian and sometimes in bad but self‑confident French.
The count rose to see some visitors off.
The count stroked his scanty gray hairs over his bald patch.
The count asked the visitors to dinner.
Sometimes on his way back from the anteroom, the count passed through the conservatory and pantry into the large marble dining hall.
In the large marble dining hall, tables were being set out for eighty people.
The footmen were bringing in silver and china.
The footmen were moving tables.
The footmen were unfolding damask table linen.
The count called Dmítri Vasílevich.
Dmítri Vasílevich was a man of good family.
Dmítri Vasílevich was the manager of all the count’s affairs.
The count looked with pleasure at the enormous table.
The count said, "Well, Dmítri, you’ll see that things are all as they should be? That’s right! The great thing is the serving, that’s it."
The count sighed complacently.
The count returned to the drawing room.
The countess’s gigantic footman announced "Márya Lvóvna Karágina and her daughter!" in a bass voice.
The footman entered the drawing room.
The countess reflected a moment.
The countess took a pinch from a gold snuffbox with her husband’s portrait on it.
The countess said, "I’m quite worn out by these callers. However, I’ll see her and no more. She is so affected. Ask her in," to the footman in a sad voice.
The countess said to the footman, "Very well, finish me off."
A tall, stout, and proud-looking woman entered the drawing room.
The woman had a round-faced smiling daughter.
Their dresses rustled.
